title: Can space-time exist without matter? - Quora

response.answer_text: So, let's make a single brave assumption, which we need to get any further. Brave assumption: For questions about possibility: the "can x situation exist" questions, we should look to see whether the current best theory in physics admits situation x as a solution.  If it is a solution, the answer is yes; if not, no. Right: so can space-time exist without matter? According to our best theory of space-time: yes.  Our best theory of space-time is general relativity, and this admits solutions without matter.  The Minkowski metric is the simplest: flat space-time with no matter at all. But wait a minute, what about our best theory of matter?  This is a variety of quantum field theory.  And according to this theory, there is no such thing as no matter.  "Empty" space is a seething mass of fields, with virtual particles popping in and out of existence.  So according to this theory: no.  There is no space-time without matter, because there is never no matter. So... they disagree.  What's the real answer?  Well, it depends which theory you think will retain its form when the two are unified.  At the moment, leading theories of quantum gravity take more from QFT than from GR, so you'd expect the "no" answer to be the one to survive in the future.  But physics has a history of surprising us.

Matter is defined as that which has mass and occupies space. Nothing at the quantum scale occupies space. Matter doesn't exist. So technically, yes. But by matter you probably mean quanta, or possibly even the quantum fields which give rise to quanta. The fields are arguably the most fundamental aspect of the universe. Without them, one must wonder about the meaning of exist. Yes, space-time exists relative to itself, as does anything. But without the fields it wouldn't have its malleable properties. I think of the fields as terms of a single field. I think of space-time as both its domain and co-domain. This allows the universe to be defined by a single concept, as the field is a function which can't exist without a domain and a co-domain. And I don't try to define exist in any absolute sense.

Space and time are metrics, not objects, materials or forces. Matter is a material with force. Space and time measure the size and motion of objects like matter. Space is the metric of distances and time is the metric of changes in the rate and duration of actions. Essentially, space and time are ideas, not things.

Yes, accelerate the observer, and you get the same result as a massive planet billions of times its size. That is the Equivalence Principle, deny that. But first ask yourself how an observer accelerating at 9.8m/s^2 curves spacetime as much as Earth. Spacetime does not exist, and it is certainly not curved. Remove any orthogonal motion relative to the observer, the curved trajectory disappears. Relative acceleration of the observer or the light while the other is in inertial motion at 90 degrees to the first and curvature is detected in the trajectory. Drop a ball in a box that is being accelerated, the ball falls straight down, not curved. Gravity accelerates light relative to an observer at the surface, which gives the exact same answer if the observer is accelerated.
